instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1932: What is A1932? A1932 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2018, 2019 with EMC 3184, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01521..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP3V3_G3S: What is PP3V3_G3S? PP3V3_G3S is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3S standby state. .
definitions.P3V3G3S_EN: What is P3V3G3S_EN? P3VG3S_EN is a signal that turns on the PP3V3_G3S power rail. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0A
threads.message:
Hi, got this mac <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> for repair. Board looks clean, never been repaired before, no corrosion or traces of liquid damage

Bare board with no battery stays at 5v 0.09-0.1 amps
When battery connected  - switching to 20 volts, 0 amps

Didn't find any short on board.
F6700 was blown, changed with new one
L7030 had a small crack, also changed
<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7040</TRANSISTOR> changed


<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.2
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> 3.3
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>P3V3G3S_EN</SIGNAL> - 0

Enable signal for <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S</SIGNAL> comes from <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, replaced it with a new chip, no changes
There should be some power lines created before <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S</SIGNAL> to make <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> start work and send out enable signal?

Mac can be recognized in DFU state, reviving or restoring device ends up with an error.

Any ideas guys?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0A
threads.message:
What error do you get on DFU?
Remove small audio board and check for liquid sign on its both sides.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0A
threads.message:
AMRestoreErrorDomain, Error 6 - Failed to handle message type StatusMsg (Operation failed)

And i noticed that board is always in DFU mode. As soon as i plug in cable from one mac to another - it shoes up DFU mode

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0A
threads.message:
Looks like T2 problem.
Board shouldn't go to DFU on its own; unless <SIGNAL>SOC_FORCE_DFU</SIGNAL> signal is hardware forced.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0A
threads.message: Is it possible to install T2 from donor board and restore firmware? Or reball it? Never tryed to fix T2...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0A
threads.message:
You can experiment few things, if have time.
First step, replace T2 and check what happens in DFU.
If no good, replace SOC ROM too.
Also NANDs chip may need to be replaced.
Be aware, all these MUST be from the same board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0A
threads.message: Oh, i thought i can use any T2 chip...Don't have the same donor board at the moment. Ok, anyway thank for helping!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0A
threads.message:
If changing only T2 chip is not sufficient, means it requires some specific data stored in ITS SOC ROM and ITS NAND chips.
You can try with any T2, but if need to replace all these chips, there could also be some data corresponding to a particular board model.
